channel.title: Less is better comments on Pixel Quality vs. Quantity

item.title: "Pixel Quality vs. Quantity": comment by Pierre Arnaud
item.description: 200 ppi is definitely the way to go. It is a pity that IBM stopped producing the T221 monitor (3840x2400 at 200ppi), because this is a manificent beast :-)

item.title: "Pixel Quality vs. Quantity": comment by John Lam
item.description: Mike - I would have definitely gotten a 20+" panel if I could get the same pixel quality that I have in these 70GX2 panels. You'll know what I mean if you get a chance to see one of these panels next to more conventional panels. Even though I prefer smaller pixels (my Toshiba M200 has a 12" panel at 1400 x 1050) I'm quite happy with the quality of the larger pixels.

item.title: "Pixel Quality vs. Quantity": comment by Michael Teper
item.description: You really should have given a pair of 21"'s consideration. Chances are you'd be getting more of both quality and quantity. I have a 21" at home and a pair of 19" at work. Two monitors is nice, but more real estate on each would be even better.

item.title: "Pixel Quality vs. Quantity": comment by John Lam
item.description: One of the Objectsharpee's bought the 201s, but the 172T is for sale ...

item.title: "Pixel Quality vs. Quantity": comment by Sorin
item.description: If you have no use for the old panels, I'd be more than happy to find a home for them (my home ;-)

item.title: "Pixel Quality vs. Quantity" by jlam
item.description:
For the longest time, I really preferred having more pixels vs. having higher quality pixels. Just this week I decided to make the switch and bought a pair of NEC 70GX2 panels:

to replace my Viewsonic VP201s:

and Samsung 172T panels:

The NEC 70GX2 is a spectacular panel. It is so much brigher (400 nits vs. 250 nits) than my other two panels that they are totally usable in a backlit sunlit room. The Opticlear coating on the panel is fairly reflective, yet not distracting at all, even using the black backgrounds that I prefer.

The pair of these panels cost about the same as just one of the panels that they replace at the time that I bought them. So even though they are only 1280×1024, I find that they are very usable. They should do until 200 ppi versions of those panels arrive in a few years :)
